requirement.topic: Description of the available commands for remote administration of xmlBlaster

description.p: XmlBlaster has an internal command interface which allows to monitor and control the server. You can connect to this command interface with arbitrary administration protocols like SNMP, telnet, JMX or xmlBlaster-command-messages.

p.i: CAUTION: This requirement is currently redesigned and not consistent, the telnet examples work but will be changed to the new XML view below (2003 03 11, Marcel).

description.h3: What data can we monitor and control?

description.p: As you have probably noticed, the tree syntax has class names like node or client and identifier which are instance names like heron or joe.

Lets have a look at the xmlBlaster cluster node heron. This is an xmlBlaster server running somewhere on the net (server.mycomp.com:3412).
heron has its own attributes like uptime and freeMem which are leafs in the tree. In addition heron has tags which have children themselves, more exact the tags:

ol.li: client Allows you to survey the logged in clients
sysprop Inspect the system properties, xmlBlaster.properties and command line arguments
topic Examine or manipulate the messages in xmlBlaster

description.p: The cb in for example cbSessionId is the abbreviation for callback.
description.h3: What is allowed to do with these attributes?

tr.td: We can subscribe for change events on selective attributes
We can ask xmlBlaster to send us the current value of an attribute for example every 10 seconds (every specified amount of cycle time)
We can ask xmlBlaster to send us the current value of an attribute on fixed times, for example always at midnight

description.p: The column Impl states if the feature is implemented.
For JMX the DynamicMBean and Notification interface is used.
description.h3: How can we query these attributes?
description.p: The following table gives an overview of the query syntax, it is URL conforming to allow direct queries from a browser and it is simple to allow typing it into a telnet terminal.

tr.td: Query the number of xmlBlaster cluster nodes (running xmlBlaster instances)
Query the free memory in bytes
Switch run level of heron to 3 (STANDBY)
How many clients are logged in to heron
Retrieve the public session IDs of joe (if joe is logged in three times, there will be three entries)
Same as above but relative addressed
How long is session ID 17 logged in (in seconds)
The uptime of all users (in seconds). Wildcards are not implemented yet.
Change max. callback queue size of client joe with login session ID 17 to 30 thousand messages
Change the language to spanish (relative addressed)
Switch on trace mode for the corba layer
How many messages are currently in heron
Access the message content of the message with key-oid="Hello"
Change the message content of the message with key-oid="Hello" to "How are you"
Return the complete key of this message
Return the MIME type of this message
Kills the first session of joe (force logout)

description.p: You can address an attribute with global scope /node/heron/client/joe/?uptime or with relative scope client/joe/?uptime. The relative query assumes the current xmlBlaster node you are connected to.
description.h3: How does the return value look like?
description.p: Responses for telnet clients are described in the requirement admin.telnet.
Mom clients receive messages with the value in the message content, see requirement admin.messages.
description.h3: How can we use these commands?
description.p: Here are example invocations from different clients:

tr.td:
The token __cmd: marks the oid to be used as a command.
Here we have used relative addressing, absolute __cmd:/node/heron/?freeMem would be identical.
For example try (in one line) java org.xmlBlaster.client.reader.GetMessage -oid __cmd:?clientList Here we change the logging level of the corba plugin:
java org.xmlBlaster.client.feeder.PublishFile -xmlKey "<key oid='__cmd:sysprop/?trace[corba]=true'/>" Exit xmlBlaster with exit value 9:
java org.xmlBlaster.client.feeder.PublishFile -xmlKey "<key oid='__cmd:?exit=9'/>"
With telnet you give the command get or set followed by the query (separated with a blank)

-c is community password, usually 'public', the IP is where the master agent runs
1.3.6.1.4.1.11662 xmlBlaster 1.3.6.1.4.1.11662.1 objects 1.3.6.1.4.1.11662.2 traps 1.3.6.1.4.1.11662.1.2.1.3 objects momTable momEntry uptime
This is a method of DynamicMBean

ul.li: For MoM clients the usual authentication applies.
For telnet clients you have to use the connect <loginName> <password> command on startup.
For SNMP access the authentication is done in SNMP
For JMX we have not investigated yet

example.p: Here is an example of a complete and valid URI, we should try not to break this syntax with our query language (NOTE: this is currently not implemented):

td.pre:
http://joe:mypasswd@www.xmlBlaster.org:3412/myPath/?key.oid=MyMsg&key.mime='text/plain'#myFragment
Protocol: http Host: www.xmlBlaster.org Port: 3412 File: /myPath/?key.oid=MyMessage Path: /myPath/ Query: key.oid=MyMessage Ref: myFragment UserInfo: joe:mypasswd

example.p: The problem is that the UserInfo is cut away from the browser, we need to pass it somewhere in the path.

configuration.p: The available commands are marked as R=readable, W=writable, S=subscribable T=schedulable, P=pollable
If you want to change a value, you need to use a publish() message, or with telnet you would use set, for SNMP you use a set command as well.

tr.td: Get the number of seconds the user is logged in
Monitor or change the trace log level, but only for authentication issues

configuration.p: See the API links of I_AdminNode, I_AdminSubject, I_AdminSession below of the available core properties to monitor or configure

ul.li: Read/Write access with telnet and MoM clients on system properties, internal states and messages is implemented.
